THE HOPKINS

Undergraduates will apparently have no opportunity
to vote on the proposals drawn up by the Student
Council Honor Commission Committee for changes in
the Hopkins honor system. These proposals, which
include a measure calling for suspension from the
University on a first cheating conviction, will be ruled
on by the Council at its meeting tomorrow night.
Council members have voiced the position that the
students neither care enough about the honor system,
nor know enough about the suggested changes to
justify any form of undergraduate referendum.
It is clear that undergraduates are being denied the
right to make a decision on an issue that will directly
affect them. The Student Council is, once again,
planning on making a decision for the students, whom
they consider apathetic, ignorant and unworthy of a
referendum on proposals affecting them. Simply
because the Council did not draw a huge crowd for its
single hearings session on the honor system does not
give it the privilege to take a matter of concern to all
students into their own hands for final ruling. Any
changes to be made in the honor system will affect all
students, not only SC members, and the students
should have the right to vote in a referendum on these
issues instead of having them handed down by a group
of "representatives" who obviously consider their
constituents beneath their dignity.

Fencers slash UMBC in debut
By BARRY KEMELHOR
In the greatest tradition of
Porthos, Athos and Aramis, the
Johns Hopkins fencing team
opened its 1972-73 campaign by
outdueling UMBC 24-3 last
Saturday on the Homewood field
of honor.
Justify Oles
The Blue Jay combatants
thoroughly outclassed their
opponents—frequently winning
by lopsided scores and allowing
Coach Dick Oles to substitute
freely in every weapon class. The
outcome seemed to justify Coach
Oles' hopes that "this could be
the best year Hopkins fencing
ever had."
For those new to the
swashbuckling sport, there are
three different weapons used in
intercollegiate competition—
epee, foil and sobre—which vary
in weight and are governed by
slightly different scoring rules.
Competitors in the epee class are
allowed to "hit" their adversaries
anywhere on the body (within
reason), while foil and.sabre
swordsmen are restricted to the
middle torso and above the waist,
respectively.
Touches
There are three starters in each
weapon, who fence each of three
opponents in round-robin.
fashion, for a total of nine bouts
per weapon and 27
confrontations per meet. Each
bout is four minutes in length,
and five "hits" against a foe
constitute a victory. Should the
four minutes elapse before either
fencer can record five touches,
the jouster with the most touches
wins. In case of ties, the two

square-off in a sudden death
confrontation (no pun intended),
with the first "hit" being fatal.
The Blue Jay mastery over
UMBC manifested itself in all
three weapons, as Hopkins won
the epee (9-0), foil (8-1), and
sabre (7-2) with almost equal
ease. Especially outstanding for
the home team was freshman
sensation Bob Baum, whose
left-handed style baffled
opposing foilmen in most
convincing fashion, 5-1 and 5-0.
Other undefeated musketeers
included co-captain Gary Green,
John Burdakin and Mark Davis in
epee; Lruce Livingston, Bruce
Oreck and John Roberts in sabre;
and MAC champion Glenn Pan tel
and Mike Brunner in foil.

To prevent further bloodshed,
Coach Oles rested most of his
starters after two bouts anu
allowed co-captain Bob Little,
Nathan Centers, and Will
Andrews to finish off their foes.
The one-sided fuel was a
warmup for this Saturday's
important encounter with
arch-rival Duke and tough North
Carolina in Durham. That meet
should be a good indicator of the
type of season we can expect,
and will hopefully justify the
"excellent prospects" the team
foresees. If s-uccessful, the
swordsmen should improve on
last year's 18-4 record and should
be strong contenders in the
NCAA Championships to be held
at Hopkins next march.

four minutes elapse before either
